Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Lisa Randall at Harvard University.

Professor Randall's research explores fundamental physics at the smallest scales probed thus far as well as the nature of the as-yet unidentified dark matter. Understanding the nature of dark matter and its distribution in the Milky Way is essential for experimental and observational probes. Professor Randall's research will contribute significantly to this effort, opening up avenues for dark-matter research that have not yet been explored. This research program is also highly interdisciplinary, drawing from particle physics, cosmology, and astronomy, with additional potential connections to geology, paleontology, and chemistry. As such, this research contributes to the national interest by furthering the development of fundamental scientific knowledge within the United States. This research is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. It will not only involve students and postdocs, thereby helping them develop a broad skill set, but also serves as a rich backdrop for introducing scientific ideas --- particularly those in particle physics --- to the general public. The PI's presence in the public sphere also encourages women and other under-represented groups to pursue science, while the PI's recent book "Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs: The Astounding Interconnectedness of the Universe" has provided an ideal platform for bringing science to the general public and has led to numerous media appearances. These activities are expected to continue under the current award.

More technically, in spite of tremendous progress in particle physics over the last decade, many important questions remain unanswered, including the origin of the electroweak scale and the nature of dark matter. For example, we still do not know what dark matter is, or how its share of the cosmic energy density can be understood. The PI will investigate these questions within the framework of "Partially Interacting Dark Matter", and within one particular realization known as "Double Disk Dark Matter", where a small fraction of dark matter particles have interesting interactions beyond the gravitational. This feature can give rise to new testable signatures that can potentially affect structure formation. Another generic possibility is "Flooded Dark Matter", which provides a natural way to dilute the entropy in the dark sectors. This mechanism expands the model-building possibilities for dark-matter physics. Finally, Professor Randall plans to investigate new mechanisms for understanding the origin of the weak scale and will study their experimental implications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a very productive few years and we made many advances. Working with several postdoctoral fellows and students (among whom Linda Xu, Prateek Agrawal, Jakub Scholtz explicitly supported by NSF), we did a number of projects regarding black hole binaries and gravitational waves, dark matter, and the Hubble constant tension.

With respect to the Hubble contant tension, along with postdoctoral fellows Prateek Agrawal, Francis-Yan Cyr-Racine, and David Pinner we explored in detail the question of how we can have a scalar field which is initially frozen and then contributes energy at around the time of matter-radiation equality and quickly disappears modify the sound horizon so that early and late time measurements are in better agreement. We carefully explored the parameter space and the viability of approximation methods that had been used in the past to show the importance of carefully tracking the field.

With respect to dark matter, with a student Linda Xu we explored how dwarf galaxy shapes can reflect the underlying dark matter distribution. In particular, by carefully correlating surface brightness with mass, there was strong indication of oblate dwarfs in the large $M/L$ regime, in contrast to numerical simulations which favored prolate distributions.

With postdoctoral fellows Prateek Agrawal, Francis-Yan Cyr-Racine, and Jakub Scholtz, we investigated the very interesting case of darkly charged dark matter: dark matter charged under its own force. We found that in principle one can have TeV type darkly charged dark matter with self-charge as big as electromagnetic. This opens up an interesting parameter regime, allowing for thermal darkly charged dark matter.

We also explored the case where the darkly charged dark sector has a light electron like particle. That case is far more constrained since thermal equilibrium is maintained for much longer. We found an allowed parameter range and interesting dynamical possibilities but far stronger constraints.

With Prateek Agrawal I considered possible point sources from dissipative dark matter. The GeV excess shows potential evidence of point-like structure. We showed how darkly charged dark matter can potentially provide such structure, even if only a very small component of the dark matter.

With Jakub Scholtz and James Unwin I also explored the idea of ?Flooded Dark Matter?. The idea here is that ordinary matter and dark matter are produced with approximately equal energy density. To account for the much larger entropy in ordinary matter, we allow for a late decaying field that decays primarily to the Standard Model. There are many interesting consequences, including a cooler and likely lighter dark matter sector.

For the lightest of our dark matter particles, we can consider Fermi degeneracy as a way of addressing the core-cusp problem which we did.

 

On another entirely different vein, I have worked on a number of projects related to black hole binary mergers. After the spectacular discovery of merging black hole binaries, I became interested in what we can learn about the black holes. In particular can we learn anything about their environment from tidal forces? With Zhong-Zhi Xianyu I have been addressing this question. We developed analytical methods to find the effect of Kozai-Lidov induced eccentricity in the vicinity of a big black hole, considered potentially measurable Doppler shifts at LISA, and have considered how having both LIGO and LISA results can give insights into formation channels.
